sentence: The S&P 500 finished one of its best weeks of 2015, rising 3.27% by Friday's close at 2,089.17.

Almost all sectors in the index advanced this week, led by shares of consumer discretionary and technology companies, climbing over 4%, with industrial stocks also outpacing the broad-based market gauge.
This week's gains nearly erased most of last week's 3.1% decline for the S&P 500 and lifted it back to within 2.1% of its all-time high of 2.134.72 set in May.
Better-than-expected earnings and revenue results from a broad list of retailers - including global No.

1 Wal-Mart Stores ( WMT ), as well as home repair stores Home Depot ( HD ) and Lowe's ( LOW ) earlier in the week and apparel retailers Abercrombie & Fitch ( ANF ) and Foot Locker ( FL ) today - along with Friday's announcement athletic apparel company Nike (NKE) was launching a $12 billion stock buyback program all contributed to a 4.5% weekly rise for consumer discretionary stocks.

Apple (AAPL) provided the biggest boost for the tech sector this week, rising 6.2% this week after analysts at Goldman Sachs Wednesday added the iPhone and iPad manufacturer to its Conviction Buy List.

Energy and materials stocks brought up the rear this week, falling Friday but still rising just more than 1.4% for the week, after crude oil continued its recent slide, settling at $40.39 per barrel on Friday.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
